\maketitle\abstracts{\vskip 3cm \large
We review several methods for determining the 
Kobayashi-Maskawa phase $\gamma={\rm Arg} V^*_{ub}$ from rate and CP 
asymmetry measurements in hadronic $B$ decays. We focus on the processes 
$B\to DK,~B_s\to D_s K$, and on charmless decays to two light pseudoscalars 
and decays to a pair of a pseudoscalar and a vector meson. Theoretical 
uncertainties underlying these methods are discussed.}

\newpage
\section{Introduction}
$B$ meson decays open the window into new phenomena of CP nonconservation, 
providing useful information about CP violating phases \cite{MGrev}.
Phase measurements for $\alpha,~\beta$ and $\gamma$, which
are not independent in the Kobayashi-Maskawa framework, are important for two 
reasons. First, they improve to a higher 
precision our knowledge of the CKM mixing matrix, consisting of fundamental 
quark couplings in our present theory. And second, they are sensitive probes 
for sources of CP violation outside the CKM matrix, and for new flavor changing 
interactions contributing to $B^0-\bar B^0$ mixing and to rare $B$ decays.
